Award.AwardTitle: STTR Phase I: Bioparticle delivery of dsRNA: A novel pest management solution for control of Western flower thrips
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) project is to develop a targeted biological pesticide for control of the western flower thrips to reduce the impact of one of the most economically devastating agricultural pests. Thrips are a global agricultural pest that carry a family of viruses that can infect more than 1,000 species of plants including a wide variety of vegetable, fruit, and nut crops, causing an estimated $1 billion in losses each year around the world. Traditional chemical methods for control have proven ineffective and the western flower thrips has acquired resistance to over 30 different synthetic pesticides worldwide. The same is true for over 500 species of insects and mites, and several billion dollars worth of crops are lost each year due to damage caused by resistant pests. Widespread adoption of an alternative to synthetic pesticides will drastically reduce the indirect economic costs of pesticide use, estimated in one study at $10B in environmental and societal costs in the United States each year, and save up to a billion dollars in direct costs by reducing the impact of destructive pests.

This STTR Phase I project proposes to develop a novel biopesticide specifically engineered to target the western flower thrips that can be applied to host plants through a single spray application. In Phase I, the goal is to demonstrate proof-of-principle for using a proprietary bioparticle engineering platform to develop the biopesticide. The technical hurdles that will be addressed include 1) demonstrating that the bioparticle can be ingested by thrips, 2) showing that delivery of the biopesticide to the thrips gut is sufficient to reduce fitness, and 3) identifying the optimal bioparticle formulation for further testing. The first technical objective will focus on the engineering and characterization of a variety of bioparticles that will be tested for efficacy in thrips in Technical Objective 2. Successful completion of this project will provide a prototype biopesticide with a demonstrated effect on the fitness of the western flower thrips. With this prototype, the plan is to proceed to greenhouse and small field trials to inform further product refinement prior to large scale field testing. Successful completion of this project will not only enable the development of a thrips biocide but will provide proof-of-concept for adapting such bioparticle-based biopesticides to target a range of additional insect pests.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was focused on developing a new kind of safe and specific pesticide for use in protecting crops. It has been estimated that by 2050 we will need to produce 50% more food to meet the needs of our growing population, yet the combined effects of globalization, monoculture, and climate change have increased the threat of insect pests and phytopathogens. While synthetic pesticides offer a relatively effective means of crop protection, there are many detrimental health effects from pesticide use and target organisms often develop resistance to man-made pesticides. RNA interference (RNAi) is a natural, biological process in which RNA molecules inhibit gene expression or translation, by neutralizing targeted mRNA molecules. In 2006, The Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine was awarded to Andrew Fire and Craig Mello for their work in RNAi in the flatworm nematode, C. elegans. Since then, it has proven to be challenging to translate the promise of RNAi-based technologies to develop RNAi-based pesticides for insects, weeds, and fungal pathogens. Years of research efforts by multiple groups have been devoted to identifying specific RNAi targets for use in pest control and scaling production. However, once scaled production was achieved, it became clear that the major barrier to RNAi-based pest control technologies is delivery. Indeed, ensuring stable and efficient delivery of the pesticide RNA in the field setting proved to be incredibly challenging, due to both the inherent instability of the RNA and difficulties in delivering it to the pest, weed, or pathogen.

AgroSpheres has been developing a novel technology for packaging RNA that enhances both the stability and delivery and allows for spray application in the field. This Phase I proposal focused on enhancing our technology to produce and deliver dsRNA to a hard-to-kill, economically important pest. We demonstrated proof-of-concept that our prototype RNAi-based pesticide can kill the pest, as well as interfere with development of surviving larvae. These efforts demonstrate proof-of-feasibility for our technology, de-risk further development in Phase II, and bring us closer to a safe, effective pesticide for control of the fall armyworm.

Beyond the scope of this initial product in development, the work performed in this Phase I project informs the development of AgroSpheres? platform for delivery of specific RNAi-based pesticides to a host of additional insect pests. Widespread adoption of this alternative to synthetic pesticides will drastically reduce the indirect economic costs of pesticide use, estimated in one study at $10B in environmental and societal costs in the United States each year. Importantly, a large fraction of these costs are direct symptoms of the off-target exposure of synthetic pesticides. It is estimated that there are $1.1B in public health care costs, $2.2B in costs due to killing off-target organisms, and $2B in costs due to groundwater and soil contamination. The use of RNAi to control pests will remove the problems of off-target exposure, significantly reducing the indirect societal costs of pesticides, and avoiding the development of pesticide resistance. By mitigating use of synthetic pesticides and therefore, the off-target exposure of pesticides to humans, non-target organisms, agricultural soils, and freshwater resources, billions of dollars can be saved in the United States alone each year.
